discipline.ja: ものづくり技術（機械・電気電子・化学工学）

paper_title.en: Laser computed tomography of opaque industrial products measured by coherent detection imaging method

description.en: The coherent detection imaging method with a low-power He-Ne laser as the source is used to obtain transillumination laser computed tomographic and two-dimensional (2D) images of opaque industrial products such as fluorescent lamps and electric light bulbs. This method is principally based on the optical heterodyne detection technique that has the highest sensitivity along with excellent selectivity in terms of coherence, polarization and high directionality. Structures of the filament and electrode enclosed in the opaque glass were clearly identified with submillimeter resolution.

paper_title.ja: レーザーを用いたコヒーレント検出画像計測法による歯のコンピュータ断層(CT)画像の分光的測定
paper_title.en: Spectroscopic Image Measurements of Human Teeth by Optical Computed Tomography (CT) using Coherent Detection Imaging Method with Lasers

description.ja: Optical computed tomography of human teeth is demonstrated by the coherent detection imaging method. The optical heterodyne detection technique with three different-wavelength lasers as the sources is used to obtain the optical tomographic images of extracted human teeth in the visible short wavelength to near IR regions. The different layers of the internal structure of tooth can be clearly reconstructed with high resolution. The image contrast is shown to be wavelength dependent and compared between the same extracted sample with and without saline in the pulp cavity.
description.en: Optical computed tomography of human teeth is demonstrated by the coherent detection imaging method. The optical heterodyne detection technique with three different-wavelength lasers as the sources is used to obtain the optical tomographic images of extracted human teeth in the visible short wavelength to near IR regions. The different layers of the internal structure of tooth can be clearly reconstructed with high resolution. The image contrast is shown to be wavelength dependent and compared between the same extracted sample with and without saline in the pulp cavity.

paper_title.ja: 可視短波長域から近赤外域における光電脈波出力の分光的特性「(共著)」
paper_title.en: Spectroscopic Characteristics of Pulse Blood Flow in the Wavelength Region from Visible Short to Near-Infrared

description.ja: Noninvasive techniques for the measurement of biomedical information are the most desirable for diagnostic purposes. The use of optical methods in biomedicine, for example, is rapidly emerging with potential applications. Photo-plethysmography (PPG) is a simple optical technique to examine the state of heart and blood circulating system in situ. Conventionally, wavelength region covering from red to near-IR, commonly referred to as the therapeutic window (600nm-1300nm), have been used for PPG. In the present study, we developed a simple photometer for PPG that used lasers as light sources and compared the pulse blood flow in finger tip at ten different wavelengths from 476.5nm to 820nm. The ratio of the amplitude of ac components to dc components of transmitted light through the tissue was measured as a function of wavelength. Our results suggest that blue and green wavelength regions are also useful for PPG as the red and near-IR regions.
description.en: Noninvasive techniques for the measurement of biomedical information are the most desirable for diagnostic purposes. The use of optical methods in biomedicine, for example, is rapidly emerging with potential applications. Photo-plethysmography (PPG) is a simple optical technique to examine the state of heart and blood circulating system in situ. Conventionally, wavelength region covering from red to near-IR, commonly referred to as the therapeutic window (600nm-1300nm), have been used for PPG. In the present study, we developed a simple photometer for PPG that used lasers as light sources and compared the pulse blood flow in finger tip at ten different wavelengths from 476.5nm to 820nm. The ratio of the amplitude of ac components to dc components of transmitted light through the tissue was measured as a function of wavelength. Our results suggest that blue and green wavelength regions are also useful for PPG as the red and near-IR regions.
